title: projectlog
text: initiate project, go ‘File > New Project…’ select ‘New Directory’. overview R project templates, select ‘projectlog Template’ (see ).  couple choices make. First, choose informative directory name (.e., name project) indicate want live PC. good practice keep related projects subdirectory. Second, specify project type. choice ‘single_study’ ‘multistudy’ project. similar, difference multistudy version, subfolders nested ‘study1’ folder. Third, indicate want keep track package dependencies. choice ‘None’, ‘renv’, ‘groundhog’. information dependency management, see dedicated vignette. Fourth, can choose specific preregistration template (either asPredicted, template secondary data analysis, empty template). Finally, can indicate whether want GitHub Repository set private (.e., visible ) public (.e., visible anyone). setting can changed later GitHub. making decisions, ’re set initiate project. everything goes well, initiation look something like :
code: #> ── Create project folder structure ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ✔ All folders and related files were successfully created. The directory looks as follows: #> test-repo #> ├── codebooks #> ├── data #> ├── manuscript #> │   └── README.Rmd #> ├── materials #> │   └── README.Rmd #> ├── preregistration #> │   └── README.Rmd #> ├── scripts #> │   └── README.Rmd #> └── supplement #>     └── README.Rmd  #> ── Setting up project dependency management ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ✔ Initiated `groundhog` for managing package dependencies ('dependencies.R'). See <https://groundhogr.com/> for more information.  #> ── Configure Git ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ✔ Working version of Git found! #> #> ✔ Local Git configuration was succesful. #> ✔ Adding '.Rproj.user', '.Rhistory', '.Rdata', '.httr-oauth', '.DS_Store' to '.gitignore' #> There are 9 uncommitted files: #> * '.gitignore' #> * '.projectlog/' #> * 'dependencies.R' #> * 'manuscript/' #> * 'materials/' #> * 'preregistration/' #> * 'scripts/' #> * 'supplement/' #> * 'test-repo.Rproj' #> Is it ok to commit them?  #> 1: Negative #> 2: No way #> 3: For sure  #> Selection: 3 #> ✔ Adding files #> ✔ Making a commit with message 'Initial commit' #> ✔ Creating private GitHub repository 'StefanVermeent/test-repo' #> ✔ Setting remote 'origin' to 'https://github.com/StefanVermeent/test-repo.git' #> ✔ Pushing 'master' branch to GitHub and setting 'origin/master' as upstream branch #> ✔ Opening URL 'https://github.com/StefanVermeent/test-repo' #> ✔ All set! Switching now to your new project at test-repo

title: projectlog
text: Milestones major update project want give special tag. Examples timestamping preregistration, final version analysis code, submission manuscript, etc. words, milestones events project history want point reviewers /future interested readers. Let’s say finished preregistration want mark timestamped version GitHub. order , use log_milestone function: log_milestones takes three arguments. first argument (…) takes files want include commit. can use either use “.” include currently modified files, can include specific files (e.g., preregistration files. See show_changes() overview modified files). second argument (commit_message) can used give milestone informative commit. example, can use commit_message give reader information scope type preregistration. third argument (tag) unique tag defines milestone. use tag across milestones achieve thing. example, register three preregistrations course project, get identical tags (e.g., ‘preregistration’). projectlog come predefined tags, instead gives freedom name tags . requirement tag contain spaces end number. latter requirement necessary projectlog automatically appends number tab tag used . example, ’ve used tag ‘preregistration’ timestamp preregistration first study, later use tag timestamp preregistration second study, projectlog automatically change new tag ‘preregistration1’. reason Git tags need unique strings. summarizing project history later , tags grouped together. freedom define tag comes trade-: careful make typos, new tags exactly match previous tags (e.g., use ‘preregistration’ one point ‘prereg’ later point, seen two different types milestones). , list examples tags might come handy many empirical projects:
code: log_milestone(   "preregistrations/preregistration.md",    commit_message = "Timestamped preregistration for study 1",    tag = "preregistration"   ) - 'preregistration' - 'code' - 'submission' - 'revision'

title: projectlog
text: Aside logging important milestones, good practice regularly log changes repository GitHub. ensures can always go back previous versions project, code safe PC crashes. part, intermediate changes important enough considered milestones. example, might incremental updates code, bug fixes, various intermediate versions manuscript. log changes, use log_changes() function: can see, log_changes() similar log_milestone(). difference log_changes() create tag get’s added commit.
code: log_changes(".", commit_message = "add data exclusions to analysis script")

title: projectlog
text: One special type milestone projectlog allows log first time access certain parts data. becoming increasingly common conduct secondary data analyses existing data following open science principles. helped, example, specific preregistration templates secondary data. addition, several established openly available datasets—ABCD study—actively encourage using Registered Report format. cases, might want document accessed data writing preregistration obtaining Stage 1 acceptance Registered Report. might even want explore isolated parts data without making crucial links dependent independent variables—example, making sure enough variation key variables. projectlog allows automatically log access data.
code: read_data(   file = "data/data.csv",    read_fun = "read_csv",    col_select = c(id, iv1, iv2),    row_shuffle = "id")

title: projectlog
text: create project using projectlog, top-level README file automatically contains code generate project history. code generates table README file containing following information: milestone: name milestone (e.g., ‘preregistration’) hyperlink takes tag GitHub. timestamp: date time milestone logged. author: person created milestone. message: message included logging milestone, providing reader context. link: link takes reader historic version project moment milestone. can update table logging new milestone re-knitting README.Rmd (clicking ‘Knit’). Don’t forget log changes GitHub using log_changes().

title: Authors and Citation
text: Stefan Vermeent. Maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Vermeent S (2023). projectlog: Tools documenting project workflow. R package version 0.1.0, https://stefanvermeent.github.io/projectlog/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {projectlog: Tools for documenting your project workflow},   author = {Stefan Vermeent},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://stefanvermeent.github.io/projectlog/}, }

what: Tools for documenting your project workflow
title: Tools for documenting your project workflow
text: Please note projectlog still active development.

title: Tools for documenting your project workflow
text: Good project management documentation crucial part researcher’s workflow. make life easier, makes easier share code, data, materials researchers. projectlog helps researchers managing documenting project start finish. three core aims projectlog help : Initiation: Set convert R project following best practices using convenient project template. Documentation: Easily keep track important milestones, preregistrations, first-time data access, article submissions revisions. Communication: Create clear, reproducible, verifiable history project—including major milestones—show others (e.g., reviewers readers article). projectlog uses Git GitHub throughout stages project. already using git workflow track changes share code materials, projectlog provides functionality automates common steps helps get information Git stores . familiar Git—mere mention strikes fear heart—projectlog set way rarely interact Git directly. example, initiating new project using projectlog template automatically creates connected repository GitHub, core steps documenting project changes GitHub made easy convenience functions projectlog::log_milestone projectlog::log_changes. See Get started Vignettes detailed information.

what: Before we start… Setting up Git
title: Tools for documenting your project workflow
text: One main aims projectlog can used people (intimately) familiar Git GitHub. However, still need three things ensure projectlog works properly: (1) Create free account GitHub (2) Install Git device (3) Make sure R knows find git device three steps described detail Vignette. Note complete step 1 , repeat steps 2 3 switch devices.

title: Construct code that is used to read new data — construct_code
text: col_select Columns include results. can use mini-language `dplyr::select()` refer columns name. Use `c()` use one selection expression. Although usage less common, col_select also accepts numeric column index. See ?tidyselect::language full details selection language. read_fun name function read data. 'readr' functions, specify function name (e.g., `read_csv()`). use function another package, name package explicitly (e.g., `haven::read_spss()`). row_filter Optional rows include results. Uses `dplyr::filter()`. row_shuffle Optional variables randomly shuffle. long_format Logical indicating whether data long format (relevant shuffling variables using row_shuffle). seed integer used replicability purposes randomly shuffling data. dots_chr Additional arguments read function, parsed string

Initiate your project folder — initiate_project
text: function creates project folder.

title: Initiate your project folder — initiate_project
code: initiate_project(   path,   project = "single_study",   preregistration = "empty",   dependencies = "groundhog",   create_github = TRUE,   private_repo = TRUE,   ... )

title: Initiate your project folder — initiate_project
text: path Character, directory project initiated. project Character, type project initiated. Options include 'single_study' project consisting single study, 'multistudy' project consisting multiple studies, 'registered_report' project containing Registered Report. Default: 'single_study'. preregistration Character, preregistration template want use. dependencies Character, indicates whether want keep track package dependencies. Options include "renv", "groundhog", "none". Default: 'groundhog' create_github Character, remote repository created GitHub? 'yes', remote repository created name local project, current changes pushed remote repository. '', git set locally. Default: 'yes' private_repo Logical, created GitHub repository private public? Default: 'yes' ... Additional arguments passed functions.

title: Initiate your project folder — initiate_project
text: initial set-project repository.

what: Log a milestone to git — log_milestone
title: Log a milestone to git — log_milestone
text: function can used log important milestones GitHub covered log_milestone. example, use function commit final version preregistration commit submission scientific journal. see `projectlog::log_changes` similar function can used minor commits (.e., non-milestone changes project.)

title: Log a milestone to git — log_milestone
Log a milestone to git — log_milestone
text: files vector files want commit. Use "." commit changed files. Use `gert::git_status` get overview files changed since last commit. commit_message message added commit Github. , can give detailed information nature changes. tag Character, unique identifier milestone. Examples "preregistration" "submission". Make sure identifiers across similar commits able link together later . Spaces trailing numbers allowed. Preferably use single word link multiple words (e.g., 'submission_to_journal').

title: Log a milestone to git — log_milestone
text: Nothing. function called side-effects.

what: Read a data file into a tibble and log data access on GitHub — read_data
title: Read a data file into a tibble and log data access on GitHub — read_data
text: wrapper around specified function reading data files. Upon accessing data file, checks file history previously accessed data files (MD5 hash) assess whether constitutes first-time access data. , automatically logs event GitHub (prompting user). useful want show log accessed parts data particular order (e.g., first accessed independent variables establish analysis plan accessed dependent variables).

title: Read a data file into a tibble and log data access on GitHub — read_data
code: read_data(   file,   read_fun,   col_select = NULL,   row_filter = NULL,   row_shuffle = NULL,   long_format = FALSE,   seed = 3985843,   ... )

title: Read a data file into a tibble and log data access on GitHub — read_data
text: file Either path file, connection, literal data (either single string raw vector). read_fun name function read data. 'readr' functions, specify function name (e.g., `read_csv()`). use function another package, name package explicitly (e.g., `haven::read_spss()`). col_select Columns include results. can use mini-language `dplyr::select()` refer columns name. Use `c()` use one selection expression. Although usage less common, col_select also accepts numeric column index. See ?tidyselect::language full details selection language. row_filter Optional rows include results. Uses `dplyr::filter()`. row_shuffle Optional variables randomly shuffle. long_format Logical indicating whether data long format (relevant shuffling variables using row_shuffle). seed integer used replicability purposes randomly shuffling data. ... Additional arguments read function.

title: Read a data file into a tibble and log data access on GitHub — read_data
text: `tibble()`. Side effects committing pushing updated MD5 hash overview GitHub case first-time data access.
